COPY
COMMUNICATIONS RESEARCH PROJECT
of the Broadcasting and Film Commission
NATIONAL COUNCIL OF THE CHURCHES OF CHRIST IN THE UNITED STATES
Conducted under the supervision of Yale University Divinity School
409 Prospect Street, New Haven 11, Connecticut
August 7, 1953
Dr. George E. Probst
University of Chicago
Chicago 37# Illinois
Dear Georges
I have just received from Dallas Smythe the report of the New Haven
television monitoring study. Naturally, I think it is a fine job
since my staff did it.
The purpose of this letter is to make sure we are entirely clear as
to relationships between the NAEB and the Communications Research Pro¬
ject on the use of the content of this study. As you know, the Com¬
munications Research Project conducted and paid for the monitoring
work. We did this for our own purposes for use in the studies being
carried out in New Haven. At the close of the actual monitoring, the
material was turned over to Dallas Smythe who conducted the analysis
and prepared the report. The Administrative Committee for the Gommun-
ications Research Project felt that since the NAEB had made all of the
previous monitoring studies, we should not seek credit along with your
organization in the publication of this study. However, there was a
firm agreement between Dallas and me that all of the material in the
findings of the New Haven monitoring study shall be jointly the property
of the Communications Research Project and the NAEB, and shall be open
for the use of the Communications Research Project both on a working
basis and for future publication in reports published by the Project.
I have been expecting a letter from Dallas, or someone else in NAEB,
confirming our agreements. However, I have not had such an exchange
of letters although I have written to Dallas outlining our understand¬
ing of the situation.
Now we are about to begin issuing reports of the Communications Research
Project and I do not want any misunderstanding to arise over the use
of the data in the monitoring study. I will, therefore, appreciate a
letter from you, written in behalf of the monitoring studies committee,
signifying your understanding of our mutual agreement.
I do not suppose you get to New Haven very frequently, but if you come
please donH fail to drop in on me. I do not see much of Chicago either
these days.
Cordially yours,
EVERETT C. PARKER, Project Director
